image.altText: A man in a red tie speaks in a parliament chamber

items.synopsis: The WA budget is being announced, with the state expected to confirm a $4 billion surplus. Follow live as we unpack the details.

title.children: WA budget gives households $400 power bill credit as multi-billion dollar surplus confirmed

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By ABC journalist Cason Ho The federal Labor Government’s budget didn’t put in place a rental freeze to help with cost-of-living pressures because, they say, it’s a state issue. However, WA’s budget which promises “genuine cost-of-living relief” won’t provide any rent relief either, which the WA Council of Social Service chief executive Louise Giolitto says is desperately needed. “We welcome some of the cost relief benefits that are in today’s budget. However, this is the fourth year where the government has released an incredible surplus,” Ms Giolitto said. “So much more could have been done to support those vulnerable households … One of our key asks was an additional rent relief scheme that they put in place at the beginning of COVID.” As the government continues its review of the state's tenancy laws, renters will be waiting with bated breath to to see if it pulls other levers to help them out. This could include rent caps, limiting rent increases to once a year and banning no-grounds evictions.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: No relief for renters

children.content: By ABC journalist Cason Ho
The federal Labor Government’s budget didn’t put in place a rental freeze to help with cost-of-living pressures because, they say, it’s a state issue.

However, WA’s budget which promises “genuine cost-of-living relief” won’t provide any rent relief either, which the WA Council of Social Service chief executive Louise Giolitto says is desperately needed.
WACOSS is disappointed there's not more in the budget for renters
(ABC News: Andrew O'Connor)
“We welcome some of the cost relief benefits that are in today’s budget. However, this is the fourth year where the government has released an incredible surplus,” Ms Giolitto said.
“So much more could have been done to support those vulnerable households … One of our key asks was an additional rent relief scheme that they put in place at the beginning of COVID.”
As the government continues its review of the state's tenancy laws, renters will be waiting with bated breath to to see if it pulls other levers to help them out.
This could include rent caps, limiting rent increases to once a year and banning no-grounds evictions.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By reporters Sam Bold and Gareth McKnight Cost pressures in the construction and labour markets continue to cause blowouts in vital regional road projects, with the state’s most expensive road set to increase again. The Bunbury Outer Ring Road project has been allocated another $100 million — lifting the price tag of the road to $1.35 billion. It's initial cost was $852 million and now stands as WA's most expensive ever road project. The Albany Ring Road's budget has been increased by $40 million. $15 million will be added to the budget of the Great Northern Highway (Ord River North) project, while an extra $30 million has been reserved for the duplication of the Bussell Highway. No word on new Broome prison The implementation of a new prison in the Kimberley is no closer, with funding for an upgraded custodial facility in Broome not included in today’s budget, as promised. With the current Broome Regional Prison ageing and in need of replacement, the state government has been investigating potential sites to build a new facility. In February 2022, Corrective Services Minister Bill Johnston announced a preferred prison location in the Broome Road Industrial Park, 10km from the Broome townsite – and stipulated funding for construction would be considered as part of the 2023-24 budget. However, with a section of the Broome community calling for more consultation, the government has been forced back to the drawing board – with the absence of funding in today’s Budget delaying the long-awaited project further.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Infrastructure cost blowouts in regional WA

children.content: By reporters Sam Bold and Gareth McKnight
Cost pressures in the construction and labour markets continue to cause blowouts in vital regional road projects, with the state’s most expensive road set to increase again.
The
Bunbury Outer Ring Road
project has been allocated another $100 million — lifting the price tag of the road to
$1.35 billion
. It's initial cost was $852 million and now stands as WA's most expensive ever road project.

props.alt: An aerial view of a highway construction

children.content: The under-construction highway has seen its cost blow out on three occasions now.
(Supplied: Nearmap)
The Albany Ring Road's budget has been increased by $40 million.
$15 million will be added to the budget of the Great Northern Highway (Ord River North) project, while an extra $30 million has been reserved for the duplication of the Bussell Highway.
No word on new Broome prison
The implementation of a new prison in the Kimberley is no closer, with funding for an upgraded custodial facility in Broome not included in today’s budget, as promised.
With the current Broome Regional Prison ageing and in need of replacement, the state government has been investigating potential sites to build a new facility.

props.alt: A man stands in front of a prison sign

children.content: Funding for the new prison was not included in the budget, as expected.
(ABC News)

In February 2022, Corrective Services Minister Bill Johnston announced a preferred prison location in the Broome Road Industrial Park, 10km from the Broome townsite – and stipulated funding for construction would be considered as part of the 2023-24 budget.

However, with a section of the Broome community calling for more consultation, the government has been forced back to the drawing board – with the absence of funding in today’s Budget delaying the long-awaited project further.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By WA state political reporter James Carmody: The $400 power bill subsidy will come in two instalments of $200 contributing to households July-August bill and then their November-December bill. It comes on top of the state going halves with the Commonwealth on an additional $350 subsidy for those in need announced in the federal budget on Tuesday. About $350,000 households eligible for the indexed Energy Assistance Payment stand to receive a total of $826 in power bill relief for the financial year. Much of the budget spend had already been announced by government in a steady stream of pre-budget press conferences in recent weeks and months.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How will the power bill handouts work?

children.content: By WA state political reporter James Carmody:
The $400 power bill subsidy will come in two instalments of $200 contributing to households July-August bill and then their November-December bill.
It comes on top of the state going halves with the Commonwealth on an additional $350 subsidy for those in need announced in the federal budget on Tuesday.
About $350,000 households eligible for the indexed Energy Assistance Payment stand to receive a total of $826 in power bill relief for the financial year.
Much of the budget spend had already been announced by government in a steady stream of pre-budget press conferences in recent weeks and months.

props.alt: A person holding a Synergy bill

children.content: Mr McGowan’s headline cost of living relief was a $400 power bill credit to go to every household in the state.
(ABC News: James Carmody)

image.altText: Iron Ore

items.synopsis: Western Australia's position as the nation's strongest economy remains unchallenged as Mark McGowan delivers his third budget as treasurer, and issues a warning over anyone eyeing off the state's GST share.

title.children: WA budget confirms state has the best performing economy in the nation, but there are clouds gathering

image.altText: A graphic that states 'Western Australia Budget 2023 Winners and Losers'

items.synopsis: The ABC cuts through the financial jargon to explain who will benefit most from another solid surplus in the WA Budget, and who will miss out.

title.children: Are you a winner or a loser in Mark McGowan's 2023 Budget?

image.altText: Composite headshot of Mark McGowan and Dan Andrews

items.synopsis: In 2017 aspiring WA premier Mark McGowan practically idolised his Victorian counterpart Dan Andrews, but how times have changed — and the almighty dollar is at the heart of it, writes Daniel Mercer.

title.children: Mark McGowan's relationship with other premiers is on the nose, and WA's latest budget isn't going to help

image.altText: An older man with greying light hair and glasses wearing a suit and tie stands in front of a blue Reserve Bank of Australia wall

items.synopsis: Previously unpublished internal research from the Reserve Bank estimates that Australia's risk of recession over this year and next could be as high as 80 per cent.

title.children: RBA research puts Australian recession risk at up to 80 per cent by 2024

image.altText: Coalition and Greens senators voting together

items.synopsis: The Greens and Coalition have joined forces in a move that kicks Labor's $10 billion housing policy into the long grass, leaving the government's plans at a major road block.

title.children: Greens and Coalition unite to block Housing Australia Future Fund vote

image.altText: Raging flames in a bushfire setting.

items.synopsis: Months of smoke aerosols profusely pumping into the atmosphere during the 2019–2020 bushfires likely triggered a chain reaction that influenced the onset and intensity of the La Niña events, a US study has found.

title.children: Black Summer bushfires may have helped trigger rare triple-dip La Niña

image.altText: Fire burns logs and leaves in a forest.

items.synopsis: A forum hears the WA government's approach to fire management is outdated, with concerns about the medical and environmental harm caused by prescribed burning techniques.

title.children: Scientists warn prescribed burning in WA is outdated and damaging to bushland and communities

image.altText: Google VP of Search Liz Reid

items.synopsis: Google has unveiled an experimental revamp of its Search results page, replacing the familiar list of blue links with an AI-generated "snapshot" answer. Here's what to expect when it comes to Australia.

title.children: Google is about to change the way most of us search the web. Here's what it will look like

image.altText: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price and Warren Mundine speak at a meeting. Mr Mundine has his arm out gesturing.

items.synopsis: The two campaigns pushing for a No vote to the forthcoming Voice to Parliament referendum merge, in a move that aims to unify their message and strengthen their campaign.

title.children: Key 'No' Voice camps merge to strengthen referendum campaign

image.altText: A moody atmospheric photo of festival-goers in a paddock.

items.synopsis: The teenager was able to escape and raise the alarm after the alleged attack at the Bunbury event. Police are appealing for witnesses to come forward.

title.children: Police hunt for man who allegedly sexually assaulted teenage girl at Groovin the Moo festival

image.altText: man sitting next to bride

items.synopsis: A Sydney "self-taught trader" charged with allegedly defrauding "mum and dad-type" investors of more than $24 million has been refused bail.

title.children: Bail refused for man charged who allegedly gambled 'away almost $25 million' in investor funds

image.altText: The outside of a large black building with a Bunbury Farmers Market sign and a hello fresh food delivery service box

items.synopsis: HelloFresh sales representatives told customers their kits contained fresh produce from Bunbury Farmers Market.

title.children: HelloFresh apologises to farmers market over false claims

image.altText: The two men walk outside in winter coats, Drumgold carrying paperwork.

items.synopsis: Shane Drumgold, the ACT Director of Public Prosecutions, tells an inquiry he was mistaken to believe federal politicians had interfered with a rape investigation.

title.children: Chief prosecutor says he was wrong to suspect political interference in Bruce Lehrmann case

image.altText: A man speaks in parliament wearing a suit with various politicians seated on the green benches behind him

items.synopsis: Treasurer Jim Chalmers used his budget speech this week to spruik the government's credentials and programs. But did he keep his facts straight?

title.children: We fact checked Jim Chalmers's budget night speech. Here's what we found

image.altText: Two men in suits walking under a tree with orange leaves in the courtyard of Parliament House.

items.synopsis: The federal government needs to keep young voters on side to get a second term in office, but this year's budget doesn't present a particularly compelling plan for under 30s, writes Claudia Long.

title.children: 'Band-aids on bullet holes': Why Labor snubs younger Australians at its peril

image.altText: a white 4WD travels down a road at night as a small child hangs out the window

items.synopsis: Youth crime has long been a problem in Kununurra, but a recent spate of car thefts and attempted police car rammings has leaders worried about children committing serious offences while out on bail.

title.children: Crisis talks over youth crime in WA town amid concern kids committing serious offences while on bail

image.altText: A Sydney tram with emergency workers alongside

items.synopsis: Emergency services worked to free Kyra Dulguime, 16, who had critical injuries, but she died at the scene.

title.children: Teenage girl dies after becoming trapped under light rail tram in Sydney CBD

image.altText: Man in diving gear touching the mouth of a large whale shark underwater.

items.synopsis: Making a natural history documentary is a test of patience and endurance, and Tim Winton had finally run out of both. He was trying to capture the wild beauty of his beloved Ningaloo Reef but Mother Nature wouldn't play ball.

title.children: Tim Winton picked parasites off whale shark's mouth, but that's not what 'terrified' him

image.altText: A woman wearing blue scrubs has her arm around an older woman wearing a pink cardigan as they walk across a lush green lawn.

items.synopsis: Older Australians are increasingly opting to receive care at home, rather than in residential aged care, a shift that the federal government projects will save billions of dollars.

title.children: Deep within the budget was a revelation: The way the government views aged care is changing

image.altText: Josephine Thompson is pictured with her brother eating food at Centrecare's breakfast program for homeless people in Broome.

items.synopsis: With an average wait time of 235 weeks for social housing, rough sleepers and the services supporting them say more needs to be done to support vulnerable people in the tourist town.

title.children: Broome's vulnerable residents fearful for their lives while waiting for social housing

image.altText: A piece of land with the Australian flag and the Chinese flag next to each other with a big crack separating the two

title.children: Trade Minister Don Farrell to visit China in push to end trade bans on barley, meat and wine

image.altText: Justin Tkatchenko, his daughter, the PNG governor general and the governor-general's wife stand for a photo in formal wear.

items.synopsis: Calls for Papua New Guinea's foreign minister to be sacked — and have his citizenship stripped — over "racist" and "derogatory" comments are intensifying ahead of US President Joe Biden's historic visit to the country.

image.altText: An LNG tanker

items.synopsis: Energy company Eni has quietly revived plans to develop a gas field in the Timor Sea which contains some of the most carbon-intensive gas in Australia, "far more than any other gas field that is being developed".

title.children: Italian company moves ahead with 'carbon bomb' gas field in Timor Sea

image.altText: Horses trek through dirt.

items.synopsis: Right to Information documents show a complaint about "race fixing" against Tasmania's leading harness racing stable was received by the Office of Racing Integrity in 2016, seven years before an extensive ABC investigation.

title.children: Racing integrity office had complaint of alleged 'race fixing' against Ben Yole dating back to 2016

image.altText: a homemade missing poster with a picture of a woman printed on white paper and thumbtacked to a fence

items.synopsis: Police have suspended their search at an Ipswich dump for missing Toowong woman Lesley Trotter, whose body is believed to have been put in a wheelie bin outside her home last month.

title.children: Police suspend search of landfill site for missing woman Lesley Trotter's body

image.altText: Tamarama House "Lang Syne"is sold for undisclosed sum

items.synopsis: The bungalow was owned by late radio star Harry Griffiths and has been held by the family for over six decades.

title.children: Sydney oceanfront property sells for close to $45 million amid cost-of-living crunch

image.altText: A middle-aged woman looks at the camera, standing in front of a sandstone wall

items.synopsis: A group of people whose families profited from slavery is trying to make amends for past wrongs.

title.children: Laura is an 'heir of slavery'. Here's what she's doing to remedy her family's brutal legacy

image.altText: People in high-vis gear stand in a line and walk through long grass in scrubland.

title.children: Family of missing 14yo says they're 'absolutely broken' as search goes into 10th day

image.altText: A family portrait of a mother, father, son and daughter in a field.

items.synopsis: A central Queensland mine operator has been cleared of breaching workplace health and safety laws over the death of a miner, despite a court ruling there was an "obvious" risk with faulty machinery.

title.children: Faulty brakes on mining equipment involved in worker death 'could have been detected pre incident', judge finds

image.altText: A composite image of an older man and an older woman smiling.

items.synopsis: The Supreme Court trial of accused Greg Lynn will not begin until next year after his barrister raised "funding issues" at a court hearing.

title.children: Alleged High Country murder trial delay as accused Greg Lynn faces 'funding issues'

image.altText: A white labradoodle dog stands proudly next to his certificate

items.synopsis: A rural teacher says the effort that has gone into training her labradoodle to be a therapy dog is worth it as soon as she sees how students and staff interact with him.

title.children: When Alby the labradoodle starts his day as a school therapy dog, he knows he's got a 'job to do'
